--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
> > We don't have to represent suits because they have
> > no role in concentration.  
> 
> Well, they could, if you are using a standard deck
> and, for example, 
> only red or black pairs could be matched (there are
> lots of different 
> variations that might be interesting to implement).

If you change the rules to require color matching, it
just means that there are twice as many kinds of
cards, but half as many of each kind.  It still fits
within my numbering scheme.
 
> > Let's say we use the six card deck describe above.
> 
> > For each of the six positions we have 5 binary
> inputs.
> > One input is for whether there is a card there or
> not.
> > Another if or whether the card is face down or
> now.
> > If there is a card and its face up, then the other
> > three inputs are for its identity, 1, 2 or 3.
> 
> So in this case, your net has 30 input nodes?  Just
> thinking back to 
> our discussion of Darren Izzard's shape recognizer,
> and possible ways 
> to input board states of games like Tic-Tac-Toe, it
> might be more 
> efficient to only have two sets of inputs, in this
> case 10 inputs, 
> only for the cards being "looked at" each turn.
>
> Perhaps you could have the outputs be the X and Y
> coordinates of the 
> next two choices, and those outputs could have
> connections that feed 
> directly back into the input of the net (it might be
> very interesting 
> to start without these connections and see if and/or
> how long it 
> takes for them to develop).
> 
> This would probably be a more efficient
> representation, since the net 
> would only look at two positions each turn, instead
> of looking at 
> every position each turn. 

If possible, I don't want to build any game strategy
into the players.  If I told them which cards were
worth looking at, that would be game strategy.
Now If I'm unable to evolve an ANN that can play the
game, then I might try to be less "pure" and give it
some help.
 
> > I could reduce the number of inputs to three by
> using
> > binary coding: 000 no card, 111 face down, 001
> ace,
> > 010 deuce, 100 trey.  I would like to hear
> opinions
> > about whether that's a good idea.  If this works
> it
> > makes it easier to enlarge the deck.
> 
> My instinct would be to not combine the nodes that
> identify the cards 
> with the ones that indicate its up/down state, but
> I'm admittedly not 
> very experienced.  I'd probably have a dedicated
> node that indicates 
> card state, and have separate input nodes for the
> identity.

You may be right.  I will try different things.  I
might use one line for no card, one line for face
down, and three lines for up to 8 kinds of cards.
